Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Son Preference and Sex Selection in Post-Soviet Azerbaijan

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Imbalanced sex ratios at birth are a long-standing social problem. An excess of male births not only signals a deep devaluation of women, but it can distort population dynamics for subsequent generations. Prenatal selection of boys requires modern medical technologies such as ultrasound. Still, sex ratios at birth have become skewed in parts of the developing world with no documented history of postnatal discrimination against girls. Why? The purpose of this research is to document how expecting parents viewed the potential benefits and disadvantages of raising sons and daughters, how couples first learned about the availability of sex selection technologies, and how they navigated family planning decisions. The findings of this case study will help us understand the various mechanisms through which prenatal sex selection gains traction. Findings will be disseminated among academics and stakeholders who are invested in generating policies that address imbalanced sex ratios at birth.

This study will use qualitative methods to learn about parents? Sex preferences for children and attitudes toward sex selection. Spouses will be interviewed separately and together as a couple. As demographers project that the diffusion of ultrasound technology will facilitate sex selective practices across the developing world, this study will highlight the moral terrain that individuals navigate before they accept prenatal sex selection as a viable family planning option.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 1991, Azerbaijan’s sex ratio at birth (the ratio of boy births to girl births) has become increasingly skewed, such that 10 percent of all girl births are estimated to be missing each year. This suggests a strong parental preference to have sons over daughters. The main goal of this study was to examine the cultural beliefs and attitudes that drive son preference in Azerbaijan. 

My interviews with men and women in Baku, Azerbaijan reveal the different values people attach to sons and daughters in this particular cultural context. Overall, respondents reported that having at least one son is necessary. On the other hand, they generally described daughters as valuable but not necessary. Respondents reported that sons are necessary for several reasons. Parents must have sons because: 1) sons continue the family line; 2) they protect and support their families, especially elderly parents; and 3) they serve as soldiers who protect Azerbaijan’s national borders. Daughters, on the other hand, are considered valuable for the emotional support they provide their parents as well as the assistance they give their mothers in completing housework. Unlike sons, however, daughters are not thought to be necessary. Daughters are also considered to be doubly challenging to raise because their value is contingent on their transition from girlhood to honorable womanhood. Boys, on the other hand, are valuable from birth. 

These findings suggest that productive policy recommendations may come in the form of public media campaigns aimed at promoting alternate visions of ideal, happy, and complete families. Such campaigns could promote the idea that families with daughters only are just as “complete” and “ideal” as those with at least one son.
